Hey, chief, the Water Supply was completed as planned. So far everything's up and running, and we already siphoned off a little Water.
We've satisfied our basic needs with a functioning Food chain! A few Rations have already been stockpiled.
Nifty! Now it's time to hunt for scrap and chop down a few trees to build ourselves Houses. We've already found a small Scrap Pile...
Nice one, chief! Home sweet home! A little bit of Scrap and Wood is still left over... Say, folks, did you really screw in all the screws?!
For starters, it's time to knuckle down and sort out a little trash! We've already sorted out one pile, chief! We just couldn't resist...
Looks like we got off to a pretty good start, chief! Don't worry, we know that we're in for some hard times! But we'll survive!

Your Settlers get older and eventually die of old age.
You always have to keep an eye on your Settlers' age to prevent your settlement from dying out.
All Children become Adults as of a certain age. As Adults they can be instructed to carry out a <link="2"><u>Task</u></link> or to pursue a <link="3"><u>Profession</u></link>.

Settlers who live in a House start a Family. A Family consists of one male and one female Adult. In the course of time these two Settlers are going to reproduce, and if sufficient space is available in the House they have up to three Children all at once.

Children are born when a Family has enough space in their House. 
They cannot practice <link="3"><u>Professions</u></link> or carry out <link="2"><u>Tasks</u></link>.
Despite this, Children are going to help out in the settlement. For instance, they carry Resources from <link="18"><u>Warehouses</u></link> to their homes and attend <link="17"><u>School</u></link> if one is available.

A cabin can be built to give Settlers a home. Settlers constitute a Family when they live in one House. <link="5"><u>Food Items</u></link> for the Settlers who live there are stored in the Building.
Settlers with a roof over their heads are also <link="8"><u>more confident</u></link>.

The Sturdy House functions like a cabin. In addition it can store more <link="6"><u>Water</u></link> and <link="5"><u>Food Items</u></link> for its inhabitants, while also withstanding sandtorms more easily. Settlers only move in as a family.

A Shelter has room for up to 25 Settlers. While living in a Shelter Settlers do not start any Families and do not reproduce. The Shelter is able to store <link="5"><u>Food</u></link> and <link="6"><u>Water</u></link> for its inhabitants.
Settlers who grow too old become infertile. They can also lose their ability to reproduce when they are highly <link="10"><u>contaminated</u></link> with Radiation.
For any Building except <link="5"><u>Fields and Orchards</u></link> you must have Builders <link="3"><u>assigned</u></link>.

You can commission the construction of a Building by specifying a construction site on the land where the Building is supposed to appear. If the land does not permit this, it indicates this by marking the problematic areas red. You can place any construction site, even when your settlement does not have the necessary Resources at its disposal yet.
If the land is <link="10"><u>contaminated</u></link> with Radiation, your Settlers start by digging up the soil.
Once your settlers have removed the Radiation from the construction site, they will bring the Resources needed for construction to the construction site. 
When all necessary Resources are there, your Builders will start constructing the Building.

Many Buildings have a fixed working radius. <link="3"><u>Employed</u></link> Settlers who work on the Building only work within this assigned radius. You can shift the radius using the appropriate icon.

Entrances to Buildings are marked as a green area.
Settlers can enter and exit the Building solely at these entrances.

You can rotate any Building by pressing the middle mouse button or the "R" key.
The Building will then be rotated 90° clockwise.

Streets are created differently compared with other Buildings. Klick on the land where you want to place a Street. Now move the mouse along the route the Street is supposed to take.
Click again to award your Builders the contract to build the Street.
Your Builders begin to dismantle the Streets in the selected area.

<link="5"><u>Fields and Orchards</u></link> are built differently compared with other Buildings.
Click on the spot of land where you want to create a Field. Now move the mouse until your field has the desired size. Click on the spot again to create the Field.
The minimum size for a Field or an Orchard is 6x6, the maximum size is 16x16.

You can prioritize a construction site by pressing the "Build First" button.
Your Builders will focus on constructing this Building.
Your Builders are going to interrupt the Building's construction process. No Resources are brought to the construction site during a construction pause.
Your Builders stop construction of the Building completely, and all Resources already brought to the construction site are brought back to the Warehouse.

Buildings become damaged when they have been caught in a <link="7"><u>sandstorm</u></link>.
A Building that has sustained too much damage becomes inactive until it is repaired.
Settlers who have to live in damaged Houses lose some <link="8"><u>Confidence</u></link>. Your Builders automatically repair all damaged Buildings.
Your Builders can take readily constructed Buildings apart again. A small part of the Resources used to construct the Building can be used again and is brought to the Warehouse.

Tasks can be used to assign <link="3"><u>freely available Settlers</u></link> to gather specific Resources or remove Radiation in a certain area. Only settlers who do not carry out <link="3"><u>any activity</u></link> will perform such Tasks. The only exception to this is the Task "Remove Radiation".
Up to 4 Settlers can work on a single Task.
Settlers begin gathering <link="15"><u>Wood</u></link> from <link="15"><u>trees</u></link> located within the <link="3"><u>active working area</u></link>.

Settlers begin collecting <link="15"><u>Scrap</u></link> from <link="15"><u>Scrap Piles</u></link> located within the <link="3"><u>active working area</u></link>. However, they cannot collect any Scrap from <link="15"><u>large Ruins</u></link>. To have them do this you must <link="3"><u>assign</u></link> them as <link="15"><u>Scrap Collectors</u></link>.
Settlers begin gathering <link="5"><u>Berries, Mushrooms</u></link> and <link="9"><u>Herbs</u></link> located within the <link="3"><u>active working area</u></link>.
Settlers begin to gather all Resources located within the Task's <link="3"><u>active working area</u></link>.

Settlers begin to remove <link="10"><u>Radiation pollution</u></link> by digging up the soil. 
Unlike other Tasks, here you don’t need <link="3"><u>freely available Settlers</u></link>. All Settlers who have nothing to do at the moment, even those who have a Workplace, will help dig.
Settlers will stop removing <link="10"><u>Radiation</u></link> from the selected area.
Adjusting Settlers Working at a Building
You cannot employ a Settler directly. Instead you specify how many Settlers are supposed to practice a certain Profession. The Settlers are then automatically distributed among the Professions.
You can manually adjust the number of employed Settlers who work at a specific Workplace up to the maximum allowed for each type of Building.

Settlers who are not assigned any Profession do not remain idle.
For instance, they transport Resources to <link="1"><u>construction sites</u></link> and inside Warehouses.
They also carry out all <link="2"><u>Tasks</u></link> you give them.
If a Settler with an assigned Profession dies, this Profession is automatically issued to a freely available Settler.

Allocated Settlers work in the Profession issued to them.
They will not carry out any <link="2"><u>Tasks</u></link> that are created separately.
If for some reason they are unable to perform their work, they will not be idle.
They will begin to bring Resources to <link="1"><u>construction sites</u></link> and into Warehouses. Additionally, they also remove Radiation from active working areas of the <link="2"><u>Remove Radiation</u></link> Task.

Settlers need Food to survive. If they are not supplied with enough Food they starve and die. The more <link="9"><u>sources of Food</u></link> available to them, the better. If Settlers are hungry and Food is available, they attend to their nutrition self-reliantly.

Forest Plants grow near <link="15"><u>trees</u></link>. They regrow when the <link="7"><u>Irrigation Level</u></link> is sufficient. In the same vein, they wither away when the soil is too dry.
They can be gathered up via the respective <link="2"><u>Task</u></link> or by Gatherers.

The Gatherer's Cabin <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Gatherers. Gatherers pick Mushrooms and Berries that lie within <link="1"><u>their working radius</u></link>. Gatherers work more efficiently when the Gatherer's Cabin is <link="1"><u>placed</u></link> in the vicinity of <link="15"><u>trees</u></link>.

Wild Game roams the map in herds. It can be hunted by Hunters.
Wild Game needs time to reproduce, and overhunting will impair the speed of reproduction.

The Hunting Lodge <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Hunters. Hunters hunt wild animals in their <link="1"><u>working area</u></link>. Pay attention to roaming herds and adapt the working area to achieve an optimum yield.

The Fishing Hut <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Fishermen. The Fishermen catch fish from <link="6"><u>Lakes</u></link>.
A Fishing Hut must be <link="1"><u>placed</u></link> next to a suitable source of Water. Any source of Water that is big enough to accommodate the Fishing Hut is sufficient.
Placing many Fishing Huts next to each other reduces their productivity. Therefore try to keep them outside the <link="1"><u>working areas</u></link> of neighboring Fishing Huts.

There are many different Seeds with which Fields can be planted and Orchards can be sown.
All of the Plants have their own individual Growing Times and Yields.
Plants grow faster when the <link="7"><u>Irrigation Level</u></link> is sufficiently high.
If the soil dries out, the Plants dry up too and die.
Employ Farmers to sow the Seeds and bring in the Crops.

Fields <link="3"><u>employ</u></link> Farmers. Farmers plant and harvest Crops when they’re ready to be harvested. To order the Farmers to plant a Seed, choose the Seed via the "Change Seed" button.
You can also put a different Seed on the waiting list. The Farmers begin by cultivating the new Seed as soon as the current Crop has been harvested. To plant the new Seeds immediately you can force the Farmers to harvest the current Crop in the Field by pressing on the "Harvest Current Crop" button.

Orchards operate similarly to Fields and <link="3"><u>employ</u></link> Farmers.
Unlike Crops in field cultivation, Seeds from Orchards spawn Fruit or Nut Trees.
These trees have an initial Growing Time which they need in order to yield a Crop. Once an Orchard tree has grown it will provide Food each Season.
Your Farmers can bring in Harvests from these trees for several Seasons before they have to be replanted.

Settlers require Water to survive. If they are not supplied with enough Water they die of thirst. The more sources of Water available to them, the better. When Settlers get thirsty and Water is available, they will take care of their nutrition themselves.

The Cistern <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Water Carriers. These Water Carriers collect Water from all available sources of Water within the active <link="1"><u>working area</u></link>. One Cistern can <link="18"><u>store</u></link> up to 2000 units of Water. You can manually indicate from which sources the Cisterns ought to collect Water.

The Water Tower works similarly to the Cisterns and represents an upgrade. A single Water Tower can <link="18"><u>store</u></link> up to 5000 units of Water. The maximum number of Water Carriers is accordingly higher. In addition, the Water Tower has a filtration system to filter out the Radiation from <link="10"><u>contaminated water</u></link> using <link="11"><u>Charcoal</u></link>.

Lakes are the primary source of Water for your settlement. They equally give you access to Fish. Build a Jetty to be able to collect Water and a <link="5"><u>Fishing Hut</u></link> to be able to fish.
You should also keep an eye on the Lake's <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> because Water Carriers collect Water contaminated with Radiation, too. All Lakes dry up temporarily during a <link="7"><u>drought</u></link>. This source of Water runs dry as a result.
The Jetty creates a point from which your Water Carriers can collect Water from a Lake.

Wells <link="3"><u>employ</u></link> Wellkeepers. Wellkeepers pump groundwater into a retention basin.
This Water can subsequently be collected by Water Carriers and brought to Water Towers or Cisterns. 
Placing multiple Wells next to each other reduces their productivity. Therefore try to place them outside neighboring <link="1"><u>working areas</u></link>.

The Rainwater Collector collects Water from <link="7"><u>rain clouds</u></link>. This Water is subsequently picked up by Water Carriers and brought to a Water Tower or a Cistern. Keep an eye on the rain clouds' <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> because the Rainwater Collector also stores rain contaminated by Radiation. To prevent this you can <link="7"><u>temporarily cover Rainwater Collectors</u></link> that belong to you.
The weather influences the lives of your Settlers to a great extent. You should constantly check which kind of weather awaits your settlement in the coming Seasons and prepare yourself appropriately.
During the night all production Buildings work at a slower pace. If they are supposed to work more efficiently you have to supply them with <link="13"><u>Electricity</u></link>.

Rain clouds move across the map and increase the Irrigation Level of the soil they pass over. Some of these clouds may even contain acid. Rain not contaminated with Radiation will also decrease the <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> of the soil.

The Irrigation Level indicates the <link="6"><u>Water Level</u></link> of the soil. The more Water stored in the soil, the faster Plants like <link="5"><u>Berries, Mushrooms and Seedlings</u></link> grow on it. If the soil is dried out, the Plants wither away and die, too.
You can check soil moisture by switching on the Water Heat Map.

Contaminated rain increases the <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> in the soil. There are three kinds of contaminated rain. Each type of rain pushes the Radiation Level to its respective value. Acid rain increases the Irrigation Level of the soil just like normal rain.

During a drought the soil dries out and <link="5"><u>Plants as well as Seedlings</u></link> wither away.
All <link="6"><u>Lakes</u></link> dry up at the same time. Water returns to the Lakes at the end of a drought.

Some droughts are accompanied by a sandstorm. The sandstorm influences the <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> of the soil. Settlers caught in a sandstorm move slower. 
Any Building hit by a sandstorm will also be <link="1"><u>damaged</u></link> and (if not repaired) eventually become unusable.

The Weather Station enables you to see if rain clouds are contaminated with Radiation or not.
If they are contaminated, you see how strong their Radiation Level is, too.
Here you can also set at which point your <link="5"><u>Fields and Orchards</u></link> as well as your <link="6"><u>Rainwater Collectors</u></link> ought to be covered so that they are spared from contaminated rain.

The Irrigation Plant <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Irrigators. 
The Irrigator transports Water from the <link="6"><u>Water Tower</u></link> or the Cistern to the Plant System.
Once activated, the Plant System increases the Irrigation Level of the soil in the <link="1"><u>working area</u></link>.
The higher the Irrigation Level is supposed to be, the more Water is going to be consumed during Irrigation. During a drought the Irrigation Plant System consumes even more Water.
If the Water is contaminated with Radiation, the <link="10"><u>Radiation Level</u></link> in the Plant System working area increases as well.
In turn, Water not contaminated with Radiation reduces the Radiation Level.

Many different factors influence the Confidence of your Settlers. Discontented Settlers need longer <link="4"><u>to multiply</u></link>.
In the case of Settlers whose Health status is low, in other words poor, the walking speed will be reduced.
Settlers can visit a Campfire and spend some time there to temporarily boost their Confidence.

The Cemetery <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Morticians. Morticians gather up dead Settlers located within their <link="1"><u>assigned working area</u></link>. The dead Settlers are buried at the Cemetery when enough graves exist. Graves are usable again over the course of time. 
If a Settler has a dead relative who is not lying in a grave, he/she receives a debuff to his/her Confidence. Settlers can also visit their relatives' graves to temporarily boost their Confidence.

Liquor can be made by a Pubkeeper out of <link="5"><u>Berries</u></link> and <link="6"><u>Water</u></link>. Consuming it not only provides a temporary boost to Settlers' Confidence, it also reduces <link="6"><u>thirst</u></link>.

Beer can be made by an Pubkeeper out of <link="6"><u>Water</u></link> and <link="5"><u>Wheat</u></link>.
Consuming it not only provides a temporary boost to Settlers' Confidence, it also reduces <link="6"><u>thirst</u></link>.

Hemp can be planted on <link="5"><u>Fields</u></link> and behaves just like any other Seedling.
Later on it can be used to make Joints.
Joints can made by an Pubkeeper out of Hemp.

The Pub <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> an Pubkeeper. Pubkeepers produce Beer, Liquor or Joints out of different ingredients. Each Pubkeeper is only able to make one of these recipes at a time.

Which recipe is to supposed to be prepared next can be set. The employed Pubkeeper begins with the work on the new recipe as soon as the current Task is completed.
Settlers can visit the Tavern. If they are provided with Beer, Liquor or Joints, they get a temporary boost to their Confidence.

Health is crucial for the survival of your Settlers.
When the Settlers' Health status is poor and Herbs or Medicine are available, they take care of healthcare themselves. Providing a large amount of different <link="5"><u>Food sources</u></link> keeps your Settlers healthy. <link="10"><u>High-level Radiation</u></link>  diminishes your Settlers' Health. In the case of Settlers with low-level Health, they move slower and run a greater risk of getting sick.

Herbs grow near <link="15"><u>trees</u></link>. They regrow when the <link="7"><u>Irrigation Level</u></link> of the soil is sufficiently high. In turn, when the soil is arid they wither. They can be gathered either via the <link="2"><u>Gather Plants Task</u></link> or by Herbalists.

The Herbal Hut <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Herbalists. Herbalists gather Herbs located within their <link="1"><u>assigned working area</u></link>. Herbalists work more efficiently when the Herbal Hut lies in the vicinity of some <link="15"><u>trees</u></link>.

Medicine is made by medical doctors out of Herbs.
It increases your Settlers' Health far more effectively than Herbs.

The Medical Facility <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Medics.
It stores Herbs and processes them into Medicine.
If an Illness breaks out in your settlement, Settlers go to the nearest Medical Facility to receive treatment, provided that sufficient space exists at the Facility.

An Illness might break out in your settlement from time to time.
Settlers infected with such an illness go to the nearest Medical Facility for treatment. If they are not treated, an illness can cause the death of your Settlers.
The possibility exists for Settlers to infect other Settlers while passing by them.

Radiation is one of the most prominent dangers your settlement is exposed to.
You ought to avoid exposing your Settlers to High-level Radiation.
Radiation exists at different levels. These levels range from No Radiation to High-level Radiation.
Low-level Radiation is generally depicted in green, Medium-level Radiation in yellow, and High-level Radiation in red. The higher the level of Radiation, the more dangerous it is.
You can view the current level of Terrestrial Radiation by toggling the Radiation Heat Map. This enables you to keep an eye on your surroundings and you can try to avoid highly contaminated areas.

When Settlers are exposed to Radiation from any source, their individual Radiation Exposure Level rises.
In the case of higher-level Radiation, the Settlers' <link="9"><u>Health</u></link> declines much faster, making them more susceptible to <link="9"><u>Illness</u></link>. If a Settler's Radiation Exposure Level rises too high, the Settler eventually becomes infertile and can even die from the Radiation.

Food Items that are harvested from soil contaminated with Radiation will be contaminated by it.
If your Settlers consume such <link="5"><u>Food Items</u></link>, their Radiation Exposure Level will rise.

<link="6"><u>Water</u></link> collected from a Lake or a Rainwater Collector containing Water contaminated with Radiation will be contaminated, too. If your Settlers consume these kinds of Water, their Radiation Exposure Level will rise.

Your Settlers need clothing to protect themselves from omnipresent <link="10"><u>Radiation</u></link>.
When Settlers have no protective clothing and clothing is available, they equip themselves on their own. Better clothing protects against higher-level Radiation.
Protective clothing is durable yet becomes unusable over time.
When a piece of clothing becomes unusable, the Settler needs a new one.

Neck Scarves completely protect your Settlers against <link="10"><u>Low-level Radiation</u></link>. Neck Scarves also provide a slight amount of protection against higher-level Radiation, but they do not shield against it completely. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><u>Cloth</u></link>.

Activated Carbon Masks completely protect your Settlers from <link="10"><u>Low- and Medium-level Radiation</u></link>. Activated Carbon Masks also provide a slight amount of protection against higher-level Radiation, but they do not shield against it completely. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><u>Cloth</u></link> and Charcoal.

Radiation Suits completely protect your Settlers against <link="10"><u>Low-, Medium- and High-level Radiation</u></link>. They are made by Tailors and require <link="16"><u>Cloth</u></link>, Charcoal and <link="16"><u>Plastic</u></link>.

The Tailor's Shop <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Tailors. Tailors make Neck Scarves, Activated Carbon Masks and Radiation Suits out of <link="16"><u>Cloth</u></link>, Charcoal and <link="16"><u>Plastic</u></link>. You can decide which remedy is supposed to be produced next. The employed Tailors begin with the work on the new remedy as soon as the current Task is completed.

Charcoal is produced by the Charcoal Burner. <link="15"><u>Wood</u></link> is needed to produce it.
Charcoal can be used to make protective clothing or to filter the Water stored in your <link="6"><u>Water Towers</u></link>.
The Charcoal Kiln <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Charcoal Burners. Charcoal Burners make Charcoal out of <link="15"><u>Wood</u></link>.
At your Town Center you can decide which kind of protective clothing will be issued to your Settlers. Your Settlers only take protective clothing with them up to the ranking you have chosen.

Tools help your Settlers in the course of all the Tasks they take on.
When Settlers have no Tools and no Tools are available, they equip themselves on their own.
Settlers who own Tools produce more Resources with each Task.
They can also increase the chance of an Expedition's success.
Tools lose durability each time they are used. When a Tool has no durability anymore, the Settler needs a new one.
Scrap Tools increase the produciton speed in the case of Tasks where the Settler is equipped with them. Scrap tools are made in the Workshop out of <link="15"><u>Wood and Scrap</u></link>.

Metal Tools substantially increase the production speed in the case of Tasks where the Settler is equipped with them. Metal Tools are made in the Workshop out of <link="15"><u>Wood, Scrap</u></link> and <link="16"><u>Metal</u></link>.

The Workshop <link="1"><u>employs</u></link> Technicians. Technicians make Scrap Tools and Metal Tools out of <link="15"><u>Wood, Scrap</u></link> and <link="16"><u>Metal</u></link>. You can decide which type is supposed to be produced next. The employed Technician begins with the work on the new type as soon as the current Task is completed.

You can supply your Buildings with Electricity by hooking them up to a Power Grid.
In the case of Buildings that are connected to the Power Grid,  the working hours decrease during <link="7"><u>daytime as well as nighttime</u></link>. Each Building that is supplied with Electricity consumes a certain amount of the total Power Supply for as long as it is connected.

You can manually enable or disable the Power Consumption of any Building hooked up to the Power Grid. When sufficient Electricity is not available, the Power Grid will be deactivated until enough energy is available again. When a House is hooked up to the Power Grid and Electricity is flowing, the inhabitants additionally get a boost to their <link="8"><u>Confidence</u></link>.

The Solar Collector generates Electricity during the <link="7"><u>day</u></link>.
No energy is generated at night.
A Battery can store surplus Electricity until it is fully charged. At <link="7"><u>night</u></link> this Electricity is used to supply all connected Buildings with energy until the Battery is empty.
Power Lines connect Buildings to the Power Grid.

Some of the older Ruins in your region could still contain valuable Resources like <link="16"><u>Plastic, Metal</u></link> or similar items. You might also find <link="5"><u>new Seeds for your Fields and Orchards</u></link> among those Resources. In order to search for valuable things hidden in the Ruins you have to send an Expedition to them. But before you can send an Expedition you have to scout out the site first. Once you have found everything of value inside the Ruin, your <link="15"><u>Scrap Collectors</u></link> can <link="15"><u>strip the Ruins</u></link> just like normal ones.

You can send Scouts to certain Ruins to unlock them for future Expeditions.
A Scout will visit the Ruin and then return with more precise information about it.
This information also includes the types of Advantages that might be helpful during the Expedition.

As soon as you have scouted out a Ruin you can send some of your Settlers on an Expedition.
You must individually specify which Settlers you want to send on an Expedition. Keep the Advantages in mind and provide your Settlers with sufficient Rations for their Expedition.

Advantages hold sway over your Expedition's prospects for success. These Advantages can vary a great deal and each Ruin has its own individual Advantages. Your Scouts will give you information about which Advantages are helpful for the Expedition.

Sending Settlers off on an Expedition takes place together with Rations. These Rations consist of <link="6"><u>Water</u></link> and <link="5"><u>Food</u></link>.
All of your Explorers need Rations so that their needs can be taken into account during the journey to the Ruin. Each time they complete a Task during an Expedition they will also use up a Ration.

The Expedition Station <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Scouts. Scouts produce Rations. You can also send them to scout out Ruins. Expeditions are started from an Expedition Station, too. You can only build one Expedition Station in your settlement.

Scrap is one of the key Resources for your settlement.
Many Buildings require Scrap in order to be <link="1"><u>built</u></link>. It is also needed to obtain <link="16"><u>refined Resources</u></link> such as <link="16"><u>Cloth</u></link> and <link="16"><u>Plastic</u></link>, and to make <link="12"><u>Tools</u></link>.

Scrap Piles contain a varying amount of Scrap, depending on their size.
Scrap Piles can be amassed either via the <link="2"><u>Gather Up Scrap Task</u></link> or by Scrap Collectors.
Scrap Ruins contain larger amounts of Scrap. They can only be taken apart by Scrap Collectors.

The Scrapyard <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Scrap Collectors. Scrap Collectors collect the Scrap located within their <link="1"><u>assigned working area</u></link>. Scrap Collectors work more efficiently when the Scrapyard <link="1"><u> is placed in the vicinity of several Scrap Piles or Scrap Ruins.

Wood is one of the key Resources for your settlement.
Many Buildings require Wood for their <link="1"><u>construction</u></link>. It is also needed to make <link="11"><u>Charcoal</u></link> and for making <link="12"><u>Tools</u></link>.

Trees grow everywhere on the Map. Depending on their size and age, they supply a certain amount of Wood.
They can be chopped down, either with the help of the <link="2"><u>Gather Wood Task</u></link> or by Foresters.
If the <link="7"><u>Irrigation Level</u></link> is sufficient, <link="1"><u>Mushrooms and Berries</u></link> begin to grow near them.
Foresters can reforest cleared areas.

The Forester Lodge <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Foresters. Foresters collect Wood located within their <link="1#2"><u>assigned working area</u></link>. Foresters work more efficiently when the Forester Lodger is erected in the vicinity of some <link="15"><u>trees</u></link>. Foresters can equally plant new trees. The Forester Lodge can be set so that it chops down or plants trees, or performs both at the same time.

Many Buildings require refined Resources for their <link="1"><u>construction</u></link>.
Formulas for products like <link="1"><u>protective clothing</u></link> or <link="12"><u>Metal Tools</u></link> are needed, too.
These Resources are manufactured from <link="15"><u>Scrap</u></link>.

Cloth is used in the <link="1"><u>construction</u></link> of certain Buildings such as the <link="11"><u>Tailor's Shop</u></link> or the <link="4"><u>Shelter</u></link>.
It is also a crucial component of the <link="11"><u>protective clothing</u></link> your Tailors are able to make.

Metal is used in the <link="1"><u>construction</u></link> of certain Buildings such as the <link="12"><u>Expedition Station</u></link> or the <link="12"><u>Workshop</u></link>.
It is also a crucial component for making <link="12"><u>Metal Tools</u></link>.

Plastic is used in the <link="1"><u>construction</u></link> of certain Buildings such as <link="6"><u>Rainwater Collectors</u></link> or the <link="7"><u>Irrigation Plant System</u></link>.
It is also a crucial component of <link="11"><u>Activated Carbon Masks and Radiation Suits</u></link>.
Electronics are used above all in the <link="1"><u>construction</u></link> of <link="13"><u>Electricity Buildings</u></link> or special Buildings such as the <link="9"><u>Medical Facility</u></link>.

The Recycler <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Refiners. Recyclers produce refined Resources from <link="15"><u>Scrap</u></link>.
Each Refiner can only produce one of these resources at a time. 
You can set which Resource is supposed to be produced next. The employed Refiner begins with the work on the new Resource as soon as the current Task is completed.

The Refinery functions in a way similar to the Recycler and equally <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Refiners.
Unlike the Recycler, a Refinery produces all refined Resources simultaneously. It cycles each Resource through automatically.
The Refinery is also able to deploy a much larger number of Refiners and needs less time to produce each individual Resource.

Educated Settlers complete every Task assigned to them faster than Uneducated Settlers.
Educated Settlers are also able to utilize their <link="12"><u>Tools</u></link> and <link="11"><u>protective clothing</u></link> more effectively.
Their Tools and protective clothing last twice as long. 
The more settlers who are educated, the more efficiently your settlement will function. To be regarded as educated, the settler must have gone to school during his/her childhood.
The School <link="3"><u>employs</u></link> Teachers. As long as sufficient space is available and a Teacher is present, Children will attend school and get educated.

Each Resource must be stored so that it can be redistributed by your Settlers.
Settlers stockpile Resources automatically when sufficient storage area exists.
Each Resource has an individual weight and therefore uses up varying amounts of the Stockpile.

Not all Buildings can store every Resource. Most Buildings can only store the Resources they produce or need for their own production. Settlers bring and take these Resources into or out of the Building on their own.

Settlers have their own inventory. Each settler is only able to collect Resources when his/her inventory space has not reached its capacity yet. There is no limit to how many different Resources a Settler can bring along with them as long as his/her capacity has not been reached yet.

You can set a Production Limit for each Resource. Your settlement stops producing a certain Resource when the Production Limit is reached. As soon as the Resource quantity has fallen below the Production Limit, your Settlers will start production again.
The Town Center can store any Resource except <link="6"><u>Water</u></link>. You can choose the types of Resources that ought to be stored in the Town Center and change your decision at any time.
A Warehouse can store any Resource except <link="6"><u>Water</u></link>. You can choose the types of Resources that ought to be stored in the Warehouse and change your decision at any time.

The Market employs Logistics Specialists. Logistics Specialists gather Resources from all Warehouses and bring them to the Market. The Market also has a Depot for <link="6"><u>Water</u></link>. Settlers who visit the Market get a temporary boost to their <link="8"><u>Confidence</u></link>.You can choose the types of Resources that are supposed to be stored at the Market and change your decision at any time.

A Greenhouse! We saw pictures of them in the Endzone. Just picture all the Plants and Fruits that must have grown here... sadly, there's not much left of them. The only things lying around here are rusty Metal and Scrap. We could send an Expedition to excavate the ground. Maybe they'll find something.
Well, just like our Scout reported: Metal and rubble. Should we be on the lookout for anything specific, or just grab the Scrap and get out of here in a hurry?
It doesn't look like much, but we'll keep our eyes open.
If anything from the time before the incident survived, then we ought to find it underground. But it's been a long time... We'll have to be really thorough. <<dynamicmessage>>
Next time maybe we'll have to bring along an agriculture expert.
We'll take a look around. Maybe we'll find something in one of the dusty corners. <<dynamicmessage>>
If you had only packed a few of the right Tools for us...
There are Herbs growing here that we can use for Medicine!
I don't know what you expected here, chief, but the only things here are grass, filth and dirt. Just like everywhere else. <<dynamicmessage>>
Next time we ought to bring Tools along!
Chief, we found a new type of Seed for our Fields! <<dynamicmessage>>
Our agriculture expert just discovered it. That's precisely why it's so important to hire the right people!
We've torn apart whole piles of rubble and still haven't found anything remarkable yet. We'll just take some of this Scrap with us... <<dynamicmessage>>
Next time we ought to bring someone along who knows more than a thing or two about Plants.

Judging by that big green cross and the helipad, this must have been a hospital where they treated their sick and wounded. Unlike them, we won't have the luxury to get painkillers for a broken ankle anytime soon, right? Wait, can painkillers stay intact for a whole century? Hmm. If this place wasn't already looted, this thing could be a gold mine...

Looks like the Scout was right, chief! One part of the Building has partially collapsed, but even from a distance you can see that this structure is nearly untouched! On the other hand, some fresh footprints lead to the main entrance, and we also discovered a few spatters of blood...

The footprints lead directly toward the main entrance. Unfortunately, we can't look through the windows because they're all coated with layers of dirt. We could try to open the main door or break in through one of the windows. <<dynamicmessage>>
Opening the door shouldn't be too hard since we brought along some Tools.
We should've brought along some Tools for that door, just in case it was locked.
Smashing these windows shouldn't be hard, chief! We just need to make sure no one gets hurt. <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing we have a veteran with us.
I told ya we'd get in with ease! <<dynamicmessage>> Really looks like some loner set up camp here. The spot where he built his fire is still warm!
Our veteran smashed in the window with one rock at a safe distance! Smart cookie.
Ahhhh, bad news. One of us got cut really badly. We’ll make a bandage out of some rags lying around here. I just hope there won't be an infection. I think it would be wise to head back...
This door is sturdier than it looks… I'd say it was blocked from the inside with a big chunk of Wood. Presumably by the person who got here before us. <<dynamicmessage>>
Lucky for us you packed up an axe, chief!
An axe would've done the job... But we've still got our hands...
That door is a done deal! Really looks like some loner set up camp here. The spot where he built his fire is still warm! We're inside now. From here we can reach the main corridor!
This door won't let itself be opened so easily. This person really made sure that no one gets in without an effort. At least not here... We might need to find another way...
We made it to the main corridor. It's pretty dark in here, but we discovered signs that designate different departments and wards we can take a look at.
We can head to the Storage Department to see if we can find any Medicine left. <<dynamicmessage>> I bet we'll find protective clothing, too!
While reading our guide we learned that some medication never expires...
If we hadn't skipped school, maybe we'd know if some of this stuff is still usable...
Yeah, some of those painkillers last forever! Good thing our Survival Guide told us about that... We also found some respirator masks that must have been stockpiled again after the incident.

Well, we found a huge pile of Medicine, but it was way past the expiration date for it. I don't think it's safe to use that stuff. On the bright side, we just found some Activated Carbon Masks inside some lockers.
On the way to the executive suite. This must be where all those doctors took their breaks. We’ll probably find some books to read here.<<dynamicmessage>>
Our veteran tells us we ought to be thorough. It's a sure bet those privileged doctors hid their best stuff in their offices.
I'm not sure if that's our best option, but most likely it’ll just be books. Nothing else.

Our veteran had us search every corner, but it was really worth it! We found some old whiskey! What a haul! We found a stock of well-preserved painkillers and lots of interesting books, too. Even got our hands on some novels!
Just as predicted, there were all sorts of books left over. We even got our hands on some novels! We've already taken a look at a few of them. We'll have enough time to read some on our way back!
The footprints lead in this direction... <<dynamicmessage>>
Our doc tells us that, judging by the strange movement pattern, it looks like this person is limping. Pretty sharp guy, that doc.

Looks like this guy headed to the Trauma Center to get some bandages. He was also bleeding severely and probably used some rags to stop the bleeding, but apparently that didn't help much. <<dynamicmessage>> We'll head further inside.
The doc says we ought to hurry, his wounds seem to be really bad.
We found him! That guy must've got hit pretty bad. His heartbeat is weak and he's unconscious. <<dynamicmessage>>
The doc says a wild boar did a real job on him.
We'll need some serious skill to get that guy shipshape again. <<dynamicmessage>>
Luckily we have our doc on our crew.
At least we brought some Medicine along.

He's back in the land of the living! He'll hook up with our group. <<dynamicmessage>> The poor guy told us he used to be a Scout in a different Endzone and took off after a reconnaissance mission. That was 15 years ago. Can you believe it? Said he couldn't stand the dark hellhole anymore. He still had some Rations left and shared them with us.
Doc truly performed a miracle in there!

The poor guy ran out of luck! We tried our best, but there was too much blood loss and inflamed tissue. We brought him to the morgue so that at least the wild animals don't get to him. He still had some Rations left in his backpack, but some were soaked in blood and we couldn't take all of them with us.
We can lay him down on a nearby operating table. There should be some alcohol on hand to sterilize his wounds and patch him up! But we need to hurry! <<dynamicmessage>>

He's back in the land of the living! He'll hook up with our group. <<dynamicmessage>> The poor guy told us he used to be a Scout in a different Endzone and took off after a reconnaissance mission. That was 15 years ago. Can you believe it? Said he couldn't stand the dark hellhole anymore. He still had some Rations left and shared them with us.

A whole section of the building seems to have broken off and collapsed. Did an earthquake cause this? Either way, this could be an easy access to the first floor. From there we can get to all the different levels via the adjacent stairwell.
The floor is higher than we thought. Maybe it's not so easy to get up there, after all. <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing you packed rough-and-ready Tools for us. We'll have a better grip on that old concrete while climbing up.
Good thing you packed some Cloth for us. This way we can fashion ourselves a rope!
Good thing you packed some Cloth and a pick for us. This way we can build ourselves a grappling hook!
Some Cloth or a Tool really could've helped us here...
We just reached the first floor, chief. <<dynamicmessage>>
Getting here was a breeze! Finally working with real pros, at last!
Some of us nearly hit the ground. This old concrete has really turned into pudding.
Damn it, chief, this concrete is much too brittle. One of us fell just before we reached the first floor. It's really hard to get a grip. Good thing it was only the first floor, so no major injuries.
We made it to the first floor. If we use the adjacent stairwell we'll have no trouble reaching all the floors of this Building. Just like we predicted.

We could go down to the ground level, chief. I just don't know why you wanted us to climb up to the first floor then, but what do I know. The stairs are also partially collapsed. Getting down will be easy but getting back up this way won't be possible.
If you say so. Guys, the chief wants us to go back down! Yeah, I know...
There's a large bookshelf and a bunch of different cabinets here on this floor. Plenty of stuff to comb through. <<dynamicmessage>>
This must be the administrative wing. I bet they have some kind of strongroom with a safe.
Having someone with more imagination might have helped to find the truly interesting stuff.

On the first try, chief! We found a hidden door that leads to a small storage compartment. There were lots of Radiation Suits and some well-preserved Medicine! Good thing some of us enjoy reading adventure stories...
Well, what a waste of time. We found a few books to read. But still, far more interesting than our Survival Guide... It bores you to tears! We'll bring them back to Camp!
The sign next to the stairs tells us that this floor is intended for patients' rooms. There's supposed to be plenty of Scrap and Metal here. <<dynamicmessage>>
Our Technician just had the bright idea to stop by the janitor's room and grab some Tools so that we can dismantle things faster!
A Technician could've helped out with the dismantling, but we'll manage anyways.
Yeah. We took those beds apart in nothing flat! We also found a few good Tools and a stack of cables! <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing we had a Technician on the team. Saved a lot of time!
Taking those beds apart took longer than we thought. But still, a lot of Metal emerged in the process.

This must be one of the Greenhouses that people used for farming. Man, life must have been much more carefree back then. The Greenhouse itself is in bad shape, but there's a variety of Plants growing here that we haven't seen anywhere else.
We've arrived at the Greenhouse, chief. I don't know what that Scout told ya... to us, it just looks like any other Ruin scattered around in the wilderness. Not very promising...

Let's see, some Plants are growing where the Planting Area must have been when this was still a lush green oasis. There's also an old ventilation shaft that we could dismantle for Scrap. <<dynamicmessage>>
A Farmer or a Gatherer could've really helped us out here!
Some sort of Corn grows here. <<dynamicmessage>>
Sadly, we don't know much about Plants at all.
Good thing we brought along an expert!
The Plants growing here only vaguely resemble the Corn we know<<dynamicmessage>>! We could gather them and try to cultivate them.
. The exposure to Radiation must have altered their phenotype
These Plants are of no use to us... <<dynamicmessage>>. We'll just collect some Scrap instead.
Maybe these Plants used to have Seeds way back when, but the exposure to Radiation must have rendered them sterile. Which makes me wonder how they reproduce...
We could remove the cover of this old shaft. Not much to expect here, chief! But you never know. <<dynamicmessage>>
Wait, our expert tells us it would make a good refuge for some edible Mushrooms. All right, I get it...
Maybe a Gatherer would know better...
Yeah, we found what looks like some sort of Mushroom. We'll scrape them off carefully! <<dynamicmessage>>
I was told it deals with some kind of moss with fungi. Our Gatherer is sure it's edible. He already took a bite.
Well, it's an empty old shaft... We'll take it apart so that at least we end up with some Metal out of this venture.

The remnants of an old Greenhouse. People used to grow Fruits and Vegetables there before the incident. There are quite a few of them around. Hmm. Looks like some of our ancestors cared about Mother Nature, after all. You can send some Explorers to take a closer look. Maybe they'll dig up something useful.

We're here, chief. There's not much to look at. Shattered glass here and there, rubble, and an old Metal frame. Was that Scout pulling our leg, sending us here all because of this junk heap?! Then let's get to work.
Stop arguing and take a look at that!
Let's see... all sorts of smashed pots, planters and buckets. This thing seems to have had a ventilation system, too. Which is now rusty and falling apart. So, how should I put it?... Scrap.
We'll try to take along some of this stuff. Don't want to see that it was all for nothing. <<dynamicmessage>>
At least we have a genuine craftsman with us.
If we had brought along a good foreman, everything would've been simpler.
All right, not anything remarkable, but we still managed to get some Scrap and Metal out of this place.
Well, there's not much left we can still put to use, but it's still better than nothing. <<dynamicmessage>>
I mean, this all looks like garbage to us. Maybe we ought to bring somebody along who's in a better position to distinguish garbage from recyclable.
It deals with some sort of dilapidated ventilation system. Looks like some parts of it could still be put to good use. <<dynamicmessage>>

No, no way! While taking the ventilation apart we noticed that this thing had a false bottom! And guess what was inside, chief? Vacuum-sealed and just waiting for us to find? A plastic container full of hemp that someone must've stashed here! Let's consider this a gift from the past and get ready for a laid-back evening in the Tavern! Hate to say it, but good thing that Scout led us here.
Some Metal and a few old Plastic parts… I'd say that's all there is, chief. Like I said, that Scout is a jerk!
The remnants of an old Greenhouse. There are still some Plants growing inside. Maybe we'll get lucky with this one!
Okay, we're here. The Scout didn't tell us a thing, but there's a sweet smell lingering in the air here. It gets even stronger the closer you get to the Greenhouse.

The smell seems to come from a bunch of Plants growing in the middle of the Ruin. They have long thin leaves; spiked, almost jagged-looking. I'd say they were once cultivated here and somehow managed to survive the fallout.
Wait a second. This must be Marijuana! The sweet smell, the leaves... it all fits! We can harvest these babies! <<dynamicmessage>>
It's a sure thing a Farmer would have some comments to offer...
Lucky for us, we have a Farmer on the team.
We could leave the Plants where they are for now and try to salvage part of the Metal the Greenhouse is made of. <<dynamicmessage>>
We should've brought along some Tools for us. Would've been a lot more efficient.
Good thing we brought along our tools!
If we're careful we can take the blossoming little Plants with us and try to cultivate them back at the Camp! <<dynamicmessage>>
Can you believe these dimwits, chief? They nearly would've destroyed these precious little creatures by ripping them out of the ground.

If we only knew how we'd be able to cultivate this godsend... maybe next time we ought to bring along one of the experienced Farmers. But who cares, anyway? Get ready to fly high as a kite in the bus once we get back, chief!
Alrighty, looks good. This is almost more usable Scrap and Metal than we can carry!
Good, we got some Scrap out of this thing. Although the frame itself is too sturdy. <<dynamicmessage>>
We'd need some tools to take it apart.

Our Scout said that our ancestors used this Ruin to debug stories. Maybe we should do that, too. (If you see this story and you're not a developer, please report this by pressing F1 using our STOMT tool)

2. Legal Basis We collect and process personal data based on the legal grounds stated in the following: \u2022 Consent pursuant to Article 6 para. 1 (a) of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR). Consent is any voluntary expression of intent given in an informed and unequivocal manner in the form of a statement or other unambiguous confirmatory act which indicates that the data subject consents to the processing of his/her personal data. \u2022 Necessity to fulfill the contract or carry out preparatory actions pursuant to Article 6 para. 1 (b) of the GDPR. This means that the data are required so that we are able to fulfill the contractual obligations to you or we need the data to prepare a contract closure with you. \u2022 Processing to fulfill legal obligations pursuant to Article 6 para. 1 (c) of the GDPR. This means that a processing of the data is stipulated, e.g. due to a law or other regulations. \u2022 Processing toward the safeguarding of legitimate interests pursuant to Article 6 para. 1 (f) of the GDPR. This means that processing is necessary to safeguard legitimate interests on our part or those of third parties insofar as the interests or fundamental rights and freedoms on your part which require the protection of personal data do not predominate.

3. Rights of the Data Subject You are entitled to the following rights with regard to the processing of data by us in the scope pursuant to the respectively listed articles of the General Data Protection Regulation: \u2022 Right of access to the data pursuant to Art. 15 of the GDPR \u2022 Right to rectification pursuant to Art. 16 of the GDPR \u2022 Right to erasure ("Right to be forgotten") pursuant to Art. 17 of the GDPR \u2022 Right to restriction of processing pursuant to Art. 18 of the GDPR \u2022 Right to data portability pursuant to Art. 20 of the GDPR \u2022 Right to object pursuant to Art. 21 of the GDPR Without prejudice to any other administrative or judicial remedy, you have the right to complain to a supervisory authority, in particular in the member state of your place of residence, employment or the place of the alleged infringement, if you believe that the processing of the personal data affecting you violates the GDPR.

4. Data Deletion and Retention Period The personal data of the data subject shall be deleted or blocked as soon as the purpose of storage ceases to apply. Above and beyond this, storage may occur when this has been envisaged by the European or national legislator in directives, legislation or other regulations pertaining to EU law which the processor is governed by. A blocking or deletion of the data also occurs when a retention period prescribed by the standards stated expires unless a necessity for further storage of the data for conclusion of a contract or fulfillment of a contract exists.

a) Scope of Data Processing The game provides the possibility to make contact with us via Stomt in the event of problems, errors or wishes for improvement. Stomt is a service of the firm Stomt GmbH based in Germany. By making contact a query is posted on a public Community Board hosted and operated by Stomt GmbH. Among other options, registered users can reply there as well. However, the message can also be composed in such a way that it is posted anonymously. An email address and a user name can but do not have to be made available. The same applies for a screenshot of the respective game scene in which the problem arises. If you use this service, Stomt processes the posted data on its own behalf and under its own responsibility on the basis of its privacy policy at https://www.stomt.com/privacy. Besides this data, which we have no influence upon, we receive technical data intended to help us in solving any technical issues. Insofar as an email address is indicated, we receive the following data together with said email address and the user name indicated: \u2022 Screen Resolution \u2022 Version of the game \u2022 Information whether the gamer is in an ongoing game or in the main menu \u2022 Details about the existing hardware and operation system, including drivers \u2022 Time elapsed, in seconds, since the game was started \u2022 Replay – data that contains the game moves made until now \u2022 Logfile of the game with possible error warnings, including the following data: \u2022 IP adress of the local network (not the Internet IP) \u2022 Computer name \u2022 Unity version \u2022 A text file containing all information about the game map created by the gamer and all starting options selected This data is stored at Stomt and made availble to us and/or software developers commissioned by us. The software developer commissioned by us shall reply to customer queries via email or on the Stomt platform. In the event of a reply via email, the entire follow-up email correspondence shall be saved.

b) Legal Basis The legal basis for the processing of the data by us is Art. 6 para. 1 (b), (f) of the GDPR. The basis for the processing by Stomt on its own behalf for those data published by Stomt is the Usage Agreement between you and Stomt. The data are collected directly by Stomt, however the transmission of data to Stomt occurs only when you actively send a “Stomt” message. Data that are not published are processed by Stomt on our behalf pursuant to Art. 28 para 3 of the GDPR. The legitimate interest within the meaning of Art. 6 para 1 (f) of the GDPR therefore lies in the functionality of our game and the customer service for customers with whom we maintain no direct contractual relationship. The developer of software commissioned by us processes support queries on our behalf pursuant to Art. 28 para. 3 of the GDPR, and solely within the European Union. In addition, the legitimate interest for email storage here is that we want to monitor the customer service provided by our developer in terms of its quality.

c) Purpose of data processing The purpose of data processing is to render support services toward customers along with the continuous improvement of our game and correction of errors within said game.

d) Retention Period To the extent that no direct support for a customer is supposed to be performed, the email address and user name shall be deleted without undue delay. The remaining data shall be subsequently used anonymously. To the extent that support services are being rendered, the data are saved for the duration of the customer dialog and subsequently for the term of any warranty. If no case involving warranty exists, the data are retained for 6 (six) months in the event that the customer has further questions.

e) Objection and Removal Option The acquisition of data is urgently necessary for the rendering of support services. Although the customer can object to a use of his/her data at any time via email to support@assembleteam.com, in such case a rendering of support services is no longer possible. Insofar as the services take place within the framework of statutory warranty legislation, an objection is not possible.
Privacy Policy for our Feedback Reporter

Here's a Building with a weird sign on the front facade. It's not exactly in the best shape. The boys should bring along Tools and a Doctor. Aside from that, some strange flyers are lying around in the neighborhood houses: "Moonshine for the end of the world". Was that some kind of party? There's a bottle in the center with the inscription "XXX" printed on it. Oh, well, sorry for taking up your time, chief...

It's a pretty run-down Building - the roof has partially collapsed. Although, the sign in front looks like the one we had on the doors in the medical ward back in Endzone. Could be worth taking a look inside. <<dynamicmessage>>
I'm not sure why the Pubkeeper had to come along. I think it'd be better to have a freshly tapped Ale await us when we return...
I bet there could still be Medicine and other useful stuff lying around here! The door looks solid. We could also try getting in through the roof... <<dynamicmessage>>
Clear yourselves a path to get in there!
Good thing we've got some sturdy Tools with us!
We can try to jimmy the door open, but it might be hard without good Tools...
Looks accessible, although I wonder if that roof can still hold the weight with one of us on it....
We can try it through the front door. <<dynamicmessage>>
We should've brought some tools along, just in case.
Good thing you packed up some Tools for us!
Okay, we've jimmied the door and are standing in what looks like a waiting area. Lots and lots of stools.
There's no way we're getting in <<dynamicmessage>> there!
We ought to be able to get in by climbing onto the roof <<dynamicmessage>>.
, although it'd definitely be easier for someone younger
, for once it's an exciting challenge
We simply jumped through a hole in the roof. Doesn't get any easier than that, chief! Now we're standing in some kind of waiting area. Lots and lots of stools.
Damn it, chief, one of us broke broke a leg! But at least we're inside now! We're standing in some kind of waiting area. Lots and lots of stools.

There are two rooms here and a stairway down to the basement, except that the stairs are blocked by the rubble from the collapsed roof. One room must be where the patients were treated, the other just seems to be full of files. <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing we brought along someone who can make head or tail out of all these files!

Too bad we don't have anyone with us who has a grip on this medical stuff and can make head or tail out of all of it. Although, we could just look and see if we can find a manual with a catchy title...
No doubt there's useful things like bandages and stuff like that here! For sure! <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing we brought along the doc! Now we know what the pills and syringes lying around here are good for!
Although, we're pretty much in the dark as to what this stuff here is. We should've brought along our doc.
Guess nothing's been looted here yet since the incident! Here's a Medicine cabinet filled with all sorts of pills, bandages and syringes. Everything still looks intact. We'll take it all with us!

Guess nothing's been looted here yet since the incident! Here's a Medicine cabinet filled with all sorts of pills, bandages and syringes. We're not familiar with the stuff... but we packed up a few things, anyway. <<dynamicmessage>>
We should've brought along the doc.
Let's go through all those files and books! There's a whole bunch of stuff lying around here. <<dynamicmessage>>
Someone who can read better would've been helpful.
But luckily we can read quite well.

They're just old files - barely readable anymore and full of useless information about the little aches and pains people used to have. If the only problem we had was a stiff neck... what a life... But at least we found a wide-ranging medical book. Looks promising! Helpful! <<dynamicmessage>>
Good thing we have our very own mister smarty pants with us. Wouldn't have spotted it otherwise between all these files!

They were all just old files - barely readable anymore and full of irrelevant information that didn't get us anywhere. <<dynamicmessage>> In the end, merely one book with the promising title "A Quack Doctor's Guide for Dummies"! Think that'll get us somewhere, chief?
We should've brought along someone who's educated!
Maybe we'll find something out here! <<dynamicmessage>>
Our veteran told us that lots of these old Houses often have a basement where you can get in from outside.
But I'm not sure what you're hoping to find here, chief. And we're not exactly the most experienced crew...
Roger, we'll take a look at the backyard. <<dynamicmessage>>
We should've brought along a veteran. To us, this area looks... pretty uninteresting...
Ah, our veteran already went ahead. Looks like we already spotted something...
Look what we found! <<dynamicmessage>> Looks like a hatch to the basement. Everything's all overgrown here and hidden behind thick vines, but we can squeeze through...
Our veteran is a walking secret door detector!
Well, it's an empty backyard, chief. We did find some Scrap, but that's about it. <<dynamicmessage>>
If we come back with one of our veterans, maybe we'll be luckier here...
We can take along a bit of the Scrap lying around. Not particularly interesting, but better than nothing.
Not exactly our biggest find, but as the old saying goes: "A little Scrap a day and the suit’s on the way". Not funny? Okay...
Oh, we got a little distracted. What were we supposed to do? Right, gather up some Scrap...
Looks as if the good doctor got a kick out of making moonshine on the sly! It's a full-scale distillery down here: pots, bottles, ... Whatever’s needed seems to be here!
Then hurry up and get down there!
Let's take a closer look at this baby! Still looks as if it's in good shape. We could tidy this thing up and brew our own liquor! But, it could be dangerous...<<dynamicmessage>>
Damn, we don't have our Pubkeeper with us... That thing would be running again in no time. We'll try it anyway.
You should've seen the look on our Pubkeeper's face. That was good instinct to take him along, chief!
Sweet, it's up and running! It'll take some time till the alcohol's ready, but good things are worth waiting for, right? <<dynamicmessage>>
Not to mention that we don't want to go blind from cheap hooch.

Okay! That went just like in a textbook! Hmmm, smells pretty awful, but ... whatever, I'll take a slug. *Coughs* What the blazes is this crap? Guys, don't drink this stuff! Everything's gotten all blurry. Shoot, chief, that wasn't a good idea...

The shelves are full of bottles - there's still liquid in some of them! Ah, the bottle with the "XXX" the Scout was talking about... they brewed strong stuff down here while the world was going down the drain. Nice! <<dynamicmessage>>
We just don't know which ones are still properly sealed, hmmm. We should've brought along that Pubkeeper.
Our best friend, the Pubkeeper, has already hurried to the shelves to sort the bottles!
Now that's a stroke of luck! Most of these bottles were empty or all gunked up, but a few of them were still properly sealed! The finest moonshine - get ready to party hearty!

No idea what we had in mind by taking a slug from those old bottles. That was a pretty bad idea... the headaches we got are murder! At any rate, there's nothing we should take along. The moment we feel better we'll just take some Scrap and split!
